comment: /* Chinese and other Sinic cultures */ improper use of term

diff.*:
Line 174: Line 174:  
*It was the first name of the [[Qing]] emperor.
 
*It was the first name of the [[Qing]] emperor.
 
 
−
*''Ai'' (愛) is used as a verb (e.g., ''Wo ai ni'', "I love you") or as a noun, especially in ''aiqing'' (愛情), "love" or "romance." In [[mainland China]] since 1949, ''[[wikt:airen|airen]]'' (愛人, originally "lover," or more literally, "love person") is the dominant word for "spouse" (with separate terms for "wife" and "husband" originally being de-emphasized); the word once had a negative connotation, which it retains among many in [[Taiwan]].
+
*''Ai'' (愛) is used as a verb (e.g., ''Wo ai ni'', "I love you") or as a noun, especially in ''aiqing'' (愛情), "love" or "romance." In [[China]] since 1949, ''[[wikt:airen|airen]]'' (愛人, originally "lover," or more literally, "love person") is the dominant word for "spouse" (with separate terms for "wife" and "husband" originally being de-emphasized); the word once had a negative connotation, which it retains among many in [[Taiwan]].
 
 
 
*''Lian'' (戀) is not generally used alone, but instead as part of such terms as "being in love" (談戀愛, ''tan lian'ai''—also containing ''ai''), "lover" (戀人, ''lianren'') or "[[homosexuality]]" (同性戀, ''tongxinglian'').
 
*''Lian'' (戀) is not generally used alone, but instead as part of such terms as "being in love" (談戀愛, ''tan lian'ai''—also containing ''ai''), "lover" (戀人, ''lianren'') or "[[homosexuality]]" (同性戀, ''tongxinglian'').
